Er to be clear, I don't mean i taught myself to be hyper-social, that part was apparent since i was a toddler and loved to roam my great-aunt's nursing home saying hi to everyone there. 

Tho also some is just shared with other ENFP/ADHDers. I can spot my fellows a mile away :D

when i was in a partial hospitalization program, a decade before my autism dx, they gave me a dx of some hyper-social condition that was technically only for kids, so they made it retroactive.

I looked it up once and laughed. It's so obviously describing my flavor of autistic.

(My mom, on the other hand, is very, very, very the opposite on all counts. And eldest daughter compensating is probably half the reason i am how i am. I had to smooth things over for a LOT of her public meltdowns growing up so i learned how to charm.)

Some of us scored on social things because we don't adhere to traditional "lets act cold to each other @ 1st" kind of things, & just treat everyone like besties by default. 

Social skills were things i taught myself from observation & books & acting classes. But im good at them.

Everyone thinks autistics are all socially awkward, but I just got off the phone with my new case manager and I gotta say, I'm charming AF and literally always have people like that gush about me when we go to hang up. 😅

Not bragging, but just to point out autistics DIFFER

"the possible mechanisms related to oral collagen administration and skin health, 3 different possible mechanisms could be suggested in this regard:

Low NE can "cause" ADHD, depression AND low BP. aka, MY SHIT.

& refined carbs -> blood sugar skyrockets, pancreas produces SURGE of insulin. So much that it tells the body to hurry and store as much of it as possible (body fat). thus most food energy goes to storage, leaving relatively little for still-hungry metabolism/muscles/ liver/brain

There is no fat to trigger cholecystokinin. There is no bulk to activate stretch receptors.

The starches in this meal (chains of glucose that are essentially mainlined into the bloodstream) increases insulin. We're still hungry bc we have not signaled the body to NOT be hungry."

This helps me reframe hunger tbh:

"Imagine you sit down to a carb-based, calorie-reduced breakfast of 2 slices of white bread & jam. How does this impact satiety? Sure there's not many "calories in," but it doesn't control hunger.

there is no protien to activate peptide YY. /

"The main satiety hormones are 

- peptide YY, which responds primarily to protein, and
- cholecystokinin, which responds primarily to dietary fat. The final hormone associated with hunger is 
- ghrelin, which is appropriately called the "hunger hormone."

"...you turn to stored food (body fat), and your body..ramps up by⬆️ noradrenaline, cortisol, & the other counter-regulatory hormones... Concentration increases. Focus increases." 

- super interesting, as i def do get a concentration/focus boost! My ADHD is more manageable.

I know i had hypervolemic POTS but idk if i had hyperPOTS too (multis are common). 

But I have previous and current experience that for *me* everything feels better while doing IF, and i've never *had* POTS during IF.

It may be that i just did not have hyperPOTS!

Now this is v interesting- I wrote a summary on Hyperadrenergenic POTS a while back: https://t.co/6jiaqoQu2k it involves increased (nor)adrenaline/(nor)epinephrine.

I wonder how these wld interact. Bodies are oft too complicated to see that as a simple counterindication but idk!

- fasting ⬇️ insulin but⬆️ insulin's 'counter-regulatory hormones', including noradrenaline/norepinephrine (muscle contraction & HR), growth hormone (cell growth & regeneration) & cortisol (triggers motivation and action). When Noradrenaline⬆️, metabolic rate is expected to ⬆️

- So, even if you're bringing in fewer calories than you're using, if you stay in the "fed" state, 

 "the body must reduce its calorie expenditure.. We can't makeup this calorie deficit because insulin prevents us from burning fat. We are in "fat storage" mode." 

& so MR goes⬇️

- Metabolic rate isn't fixed, it can vary by 30-40% based on diet, activity levels, age, body temp, & more. .. "the most significant determinant.. is insulin."

- Our body is in the fed/storing energy (as fat) stage, or fasted/using stored energy stage, can't be in both @ once

"By not eating [for a while], we allow insulin levels to drop, which tells the body that food is no longer available and that it's time to eat some of the food in the fridge (glycogen) or freezer (body fat.)"

"If I could sum up fasting in one sentence, I would say this: fasting regulates your hormones. It's more than a diet; it resets your body's internal controls, allowing it to burn the right amount of energy to keep you alive." - Dr. Jason Fung, MD

- Western diets oft include 6-7 carb-heavy meals/snacks a day, it keeps insulin levels spiking

- "High levels of insulin tell the body to keep trying to store food energy, preventing us from burning our fat stores" & just making more

CW: Food/eating/fasting

I have lots to say on that actually**

Both kids have had a hard time reading body language/facial expressions/tones of voice. I am constantly pointing out signs of ppl being upset/joking etc to teach them what to look for/notice.. they've def improved, tho we still work on it. helps tons in reducing fighting/sads!

Like, i distinctly remember at age 15 learning for the first time you are "supposed to" make eye contact when you talk to people. My mom doesn't do that. I HAD NO CLUE, truly. I had ALWAYS looked at mouths. I trained myself to look at eyes. Its still not my fave, but i can do it

Also a parent/bonus parent of two ND kids... a LOT of traits people talk about as being autistic.. i do see them in the kids, but then I just... teach them the things they seem to not have realized on their own.. and then they have learned them.

They're no less ND for it..

There are a lot of autistics who are very against any sort of teaching/learning things that are "NT"- and in principal i am against trying to make people what they aren't (in this case, NT)

But what about the things that we think are traits that might have just been not learned?

All together, its just really apparent that we dont know the diff btwn 
- inherent autistic traits, 
- what is a product of being treated differently/having fewer social/communication opportunities when young
- what is a product of being raised by parents w/certain traits

There was a tweet by an autistic a few months ago that brought up the fact that autistics are often socially shunned & thus get less socialization/social learning opportunities growing up & that may be a significant factor in *some* language/communication differences some have

So, before I knew we were autistic, I had definitely recognized at a young age that I wasn't being taught certain social (&executive functiony & various other) things, & that's one reason i developed a special interest in acting & social rules-classes, books, etc- to learn..

I havent been able to stop thinking about it.

before I knew we were autistic, I had always told people that I grew up feral bc my mom never taught me how to be a people, ESPECIALLY socially-- my bro and i grew up having to rein her in in public bc she gets very rude w/ppl  etc.

The areas usually claimed as language centers are NOT language specific tho, & tend to be executive function areas to deal w/sequencing or motor planning generally. 

I can't relate to any claims autistics make about our language diffs, & I grew up super socialized so,🤔 I wonder

His arguments earlier in the book about how, despite the researchers who claim otherwise, there are no actual biologically distinct areas of language in the brain. There are areas most used for that purpose in human brains, but it's not ubiquitous and if young enough, it can move

But ANYWAY, it's half the book later and he's talking about all the unspoken rules/norms and required inferences in language, giving examples autistics complain abt all the time & explaining how there's no biology to it, it's learned cultural information, taught via socialization

Tbh I had to FF through that chapter bc I have a way higher tolerance for it than most, but he only used the term autism suffer, &was conflating Savant syndrome with autism, tho at least the point he was trying to make was that ppl underestimate us& we're diff, not broken

This book is by a linguistic anthropologist who is outlining his argument that language it's not something we evolved but something that humans invented. One of his major point is that there are no heritable language disabilities, and no not even autism,

Back to the original issue- I even talked to sleep dr abt the possibility of narcolepsy. It feels like my brain doesn't fully sleep at night & sometimes, like yest, part of brain ISTG shuts DOWN in the day for a few hrs. I can do nothing but go lay down/stare at walls basically.

The Sleep Dr said it's almost certainly an EDS thing. 

I also know that 2/3rds of ADHDers have sleep disorders of some sort or another. 

And EDS & ADHD is correlated. I want to see studies about them both + sleep!

At the time of my sleep study I had NO IDEA. I went to the sleep dr bc i was sleeping so lightly the slightest sound would wake me up, but i had no snoring, no extreme tiredness during the day (tho im on ADHD meds which'd counter that), etc. So i was shocked to read the report!

Respiratory effort-related arousal (RERA)- i didn't have any obstructive apnea events during sleep study, but my body did apparently notice that my airway was starting to flop& it uber-filled me with adrenaline to make me gasp& thus prevent obstruction

I did that 62x in 1 night.

e.g. I eventually learned that, say, my hyperness &oversharing was overwhelming in social situations. From then on when i felt myself start, I was (usually) able 2 pause &decide if that was a safe, comfy place for me to be myself, or should i be on "business casual" behavior, lol

This could help NDs like my mom understand better how to socialize in gen.

This could help NTs who meet my mom understand her social differences & not judge her so harshly.

It does help NDs like my kid understand social situs & make informed decisions abt how 2 act in what situ

& this 100% goes for everyone on the earth. 

NTs & NDs both need to learn both the "norm" of social skills, AND diff ways that different people/groups socialize/communicate ALSO. So when an NT meets an ND w/X style, they KNOW what they're seeing & dont make assumptions of intent

TO BE CLEAR: I don't mean everyone needs to behave the same.

Social skills are just chunks of knowledge. 

YES i think everyone should have the knowledge. 

BUT when they act a certain way is up to them. HAVING that KNOWLEDGE, tho can help them understand others at the *least*.

Now, I have no wound healing issues at all, despite EDS. 

Again i really wish we knew why some of us don't and others have big issues with it.

"..contraindicated in patients w/implantable medical devices and those with underlying healing disorders. 

..studies have shown it to be less effective in older patients, either due to decreased capacity for dermal healing, decreased tissue hydration, or increased [sagginess]"
"shown to be beneficial for the treatment of facial wrinkles, brow lifting, periorbital wrinkles, nasolabial folds, jowls, marionette lines, jawline contouring, and neck laxity."

"Radiofrequency skin tightening works by transmission of thermal energy to the reticular dermis, triggering a remodeling cascade with subsequent collagen, elastin, & vascular formation. 

"It.. specifically treats the dermis & spares the epidermis, thereby reducing scarring," etc

Alpha hydroxy acids, (ie glycolic, lactic, and citric acids) exfoliate the skin & interfere with epidermal cohesion (which makes skin look young??). 

Improves elastin quality & collagen density on 1 study.

don't use antioxidants + acids!

Retinoids increase dermal collagen, epidermal thickness, & glycosaminoglycan deposition, smoothing skin & reducing wrinkles.

Retinol is 20x less effective w/1000x lower dermal concentration than the RX version, tretinoin. But way less irritationy side effects.

ferulic acid stabilizes those 2 antioxidants & increases how well they stop & reverse signs of skin aging.

"The ideal antioxidant should contain a blend of these ingredients & others such as polyphenols, flavonoids, & carotenoids, in a stable [daily] formulation"

"Antioxidants.. protect skin from oxidative stress & to restore skin subjected to environmental damage. 

Vitamin C enhances collagen production & epidermal turnover to improve skin surface appearance, 

while vitamin E synergistically neutralizes reactive oxygen species."

Rhytids - Fine lines & minor creases. Pre-wrinkles.

Sunscreen helps stop all this ofc. 

"Inorganic sunscreens, specifically zinc oxide and titanium dioxide, provide superior, broad-spectrum UV protection"

Elastosis - "UV radiation breaks down the connective tissue (collagen & elastin fibers) that lies in the deeper layer of the skin. W/o the supportive connective tissue, the skin loses [elasticity]."

Signs: yellowed, thick skin w/deep wrinkles that don't disappear w/stretching.
Telangiectasias (spider veins!) - dilated or broken blood vessels on the skin or mucous membranes. https://t.co/ebrgnIN1nI

Sun exposure speeds up skin's aging by 

"damaging dermal collagen & elastin & interfering with normal skin metabolism. Together, these derangements [lol] promote irregular pigmentation, telangiectasias, elastosis, and rhytids."

This thread brought to you by my brain waking itself up at 3am by having a song stuck too loudly in it again, and then seeing people have to apologize for describing themself in unapproved ways in adhd groups.

DIFFERENT. HISTORIES. Ahhhhh

Tl:Dr adhd is THE main and major executive dysfunction condition. (Maybe tied with TBI)

The word function is in the phrase.

Autistic history is very different.

Please stop policing how people describe themselves.

Your adhd is valid even if you can do a lot more stuff than me.

But our shared diagnosis doesn't mean we struggle equally, even tho we all, by definition! struggle in ways non adhders/exec dysfunction ppl can never really understand.

But executive dysfunction is CUMULATIVE. It is absolutely worse for some than others, scientifically.
You don't have to have a shitty ass life like I do to have completely valid ADHD struggles, people. My inability to support myself or my time in debtors prison doesn't negate your adhd at all.

The worst part is that I often see people who would not ever consider themselves/be considered as high functioning trying to speak up about the utility of this word and our discomfort of being unable to express our differences to those who can still work,etc,and were attacked

The anxiety community doesn't do this, afaict, and I see memes about high functioning anxiety daily.

I speak to my Drs nearly weekly about the functioning level of various joints and organs from my EDS. My brain has way bigger functioning issues.

But don't you dare try to take away my ability to explain the severity of my struggles. I've told doctors I can't function for a decade before I was diagnosed, and it's enragingly illogical to ban me from using the word *because* I was dxd with an executive dysFUNCTION condition.

People get very touchy because of imposter syndrome, but that's not permission to police language. You don't have to be like me who couldn't keep a job more than a few months and thus had to stay in relationships for housing, or be jailed bc of paperwork difficulties to have ADHD

Theres a v diff history behind that word usage in autism that does not apply to the history of ADHD. Adhd is a pure* exec dysFUNCTION  condition, with huge dysfunction lvl disparities. Support needs doesn't make sense in a condition where meds are the only real support available.

As an autistic ADHDer who spent yrs studying executive dysfunction &ADHD & was literally writing a book on it before covid caused *more* loss of exec functioning ability- for the love of god I need the online adhd community to stop appropriating autism's ban on functioning labels

Okay sorry y'all that was longer than i expected. I just find it very interesting. This paper is from the US military, and talked a lot about how wearable technology may be developed to track the compensatory reserve to warn folks before the hypovolemic shock kicks in.
/so that appropriate recovery procedures can be employed and subsequent determination could be made for return to the activity."

"With the emergence of wearable sensor systems that can provide machine learning with real-time measurements of the compensatory reserve, it is likely that those individuals at highest risk for developing heat exhaustion could be identified well in advance of collapse..

"measurement of the compensatory reserve distinguished actively from nonactively bleeding trauma patients when HR & blood lactate could not & provided significantly greater sensitivity &  specificity compared with standard vital signs..HR, BP, shock index, & base deficit."

"Various case studies of compensatory reserve measurements have been reported in patients with severe hypovolemia resulting from #POTS, childbirth, appendicitis, burn injury, sepsis, & cardiopulmonary resuscitation as well as Dengue hemorrhagic fever and blood donation."

"inability to recognize early signs of progression toward life-threatening circulatory shock reflects the limitation of..tech that provide static measures.. vital signs &other[s]..that are maintained relatively constant rather than measures of dynamic compensatory responses"

"Heat stress increases skin blood flow requirement, which can impair endurance performance"

Ok this sentence is so basic &, like, duh, but it strikes me I never put two & two together. If hot, my blood is gonna go to my skin to cool off. No wonder why heat makes me braindead!😳
@Be_Kinderr This seems to say the opposite.

"..absolute hypovolemia caused by dehydration in temperate conditions & relative hypovolemia induced by heat-stress can _independently impair VO2max_ with a _combined additive effect_ that exacerbates the reduction in VO2max."

"..if the physical exercise were performed in a warm-hot environment, where BP regulation can be a limiting factor for aerobic performance, then the compensatory reserve may have dropped toward 0, [as in] progressive hypovolemia in models of hemorrhage if bleeding is not stopped"
"An asymptote suggests that hypovolemia and blood pressure regulation were not the limiting factors during maximal-effort cycle ergometer exercise, as might be expected.

"..the resulting exercise-induced hypovolemia would require the recruitment of compensatory mechanisms to support adequate muscle oxygen delivery"

"Compensatory reserve progressively decreased with increasing exercise intensity..to an asymptote at ~20% of compensatory reserve"

"Aerobic performance is partially dependent on the capacity of the cardiovascular system to sustain [BP] & cardiac output. As such, greater 02 uptake requirement during..exercise translates to greater active vasodilation in skeletal muscle that translates to relative hypovolemia"

"standard metrics of physiological stress such as [HR] [BP], and body temp[] [&] measures of peripheral vasodilation caused by heat or hypoxia, failed to provide the precision, sensitivity, & specificity of the compensatory reserve to predict the onset of cardiovascular collapse"

"Within this context, the compensatory reserve represents a new paradigm for measuring the sum total capacity of all compensatory mechanisms that together defend against inadequate blood pressure regulation, systemic blood flow, and tissue oxygenation with hypovolemia."

"For example, an individual’s reserve for tachycardia associated with a hypovolemic state is represented by the difference between the resting baseline heart rate and the maximal heart rate response."

"Any physiological compensatory mechanism is limited by a finite maximal capacity to respond to a specific hypovolemic state. Thus, the “reserve” to compensate can be defined by the difference between the maximal response and the baseline state. "

"..clinically significant alterations in physiological responses associated with hypovolemia are usually delayed because of integration of physiological compensatory mechanisms that act to sustain blood pressure and “protect” tissue perfusion or have slow time courses./
